refnamediv.refpurpose: BSD/System V compatibility utilities for system and service control

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: init is a multiple personality program, whose function varies according to what name it is invoked as.

refsection.title: Compatibility system control commands
refsection.para: Invoked as one of the system control commands emergency, rescue, or normal, it will chain to system-control8 inserting that as the 0th argument and passing the original arguments as the subcommand.

Invoked as one of the system control commands reboot, halt, or poweroff it will normally chain to shutdown8 with the -r, -h, or -p command-line option respectively. shutdown8 is then responsible for issuing the relevant commands to the system manager. The --halt, --reboot, and --poweroff command-line options force which option is sent to shutdown8, for the benefits of system administrators who enjoy giving computers self-contradictory instructions like reboot --halt.

The --force command-line option specifies that the shutdown process should bypass service changes and enact the finalization action immediately. When it is used the command will instead chain to the reboot, halt, and poweroff subcommands of system-control8, passing the --force command-line option through. This will also bypass whatever actions shutdown8 would have taken, including writing warning messages to users and writing login accounting database entries.
Invoked as one of the system control commands fastboot, fasthalt, or fastpoweroff, it will act as if invoked as reboot, halt, or poweroff with the --force command-line option.

refsection.title: Compatibility service control commands
refsection.para: Invoked as service name command, the program chains to system-control command name. It makes no attempt to validate command itself. For best results, restrict command to one of start, stop, or status.

service chains to system-control8 rather than to service-control1 or service-status1 directly. Because of this, start and stop will execute service control jobs, rather than affecting individual services. Thus starting or stopping a service will affect any dependent services, and may take additional dependent actions. The traditional behaviour of the SystemV service command is to only affect individual services, without ensuring correct service dependencies and ordering.

refsection.title: Compatibility service configuration commands
refsection.para: Invoked as chkconfig name command, the program chains to system-control command name. It makes no attempt to validate command itself. For best results, restrict command to one of on, off, or reset.

refsection.title: Compatibility bootstrap utility
refsection.para: Invoked as init the program simply chain loads to either system-manager8 or telinit8 with the execvp3 function, passing along all of its command line arguments (with one possible exception) as-is.

If it sees that it is process #1, it chains to system-manager8. It leaves the command line arguments alone. This means that system-manager8 sees itself invoked under the name init and behaves accordingly.

If it sees that it is not process #1, it chains to telinit1. It replaces the first command line argument with telinit. This is so that telinit1 sees itself invoked under that name and behaves accordingly.

Because on some systems the executable is dynamically linked to libraries in /usr/lib and /usr/lib isn't present as boot time, it is a mistake to use this as process #1. Configure the system to invoke system-manager8 directly, instead.

refsection.title: Compatibility control utility
refsection.para: Invoked as telinit the program chain loads to one of the system control commands, selected by its first (non-option) argument:
It is a mistake to run this as process #1, thinking that it is an alias for init8.
It is pretty much a mistake to use it at all. Use the system control commands directly instead.

There is no q argument. This is deliberate. Its use case is running telinit q after updating /etc/ttys or /etc/inittab. Any script that is updating those files and then expecting the system manager to re-read them is not targetting the correct configuration mechanisms, and is in error.
